Absolute rubbish. Direct payment to provider is only possible with extremely good health or extremely high wealth. And EVERY other developed nation proves that it can be done better at lower cost.

"The only choice we have to control costs is direct payment from the patient to the care provider. Patients will ask more questions and be incentivised to avoid unhealthy behaviors."

Hmm . . . collapse from a ruptured undiagnosed aneurysm, get injured in a car accident, get a diagnosis of stage 4 ovarian cancer, suffer a gunshot wound, get old (what an unhealthy behavior - should have avoided it!) and develop dementia. Prevention and asking questions are not going to work in situations like these.

Agreed, there are many preventive health measures we should all follow, and we should all be careful users of health care. But cost containment needs to be built into the system at all levels, along the lines of Sherry's 6-point list - to which I would add finding a way to let doctors and other medical professionals graduate without incurring huge debts.

"The bottom line in this debate is that the American public really does not understand the true value of healthcare since they don't directly pay for it".

That's not the bottom line. The bottom line is that we are a civilized society but we lag 'way behind other countries in providing health care and ours is too costly as well.

The trouble with "direct payment from the patient to the care provider" is that most people can't afford anything other than the barest minimum of medical costs unless they are insured.

Some costs: knee replacement ($15,000 - 25,000), congestive heart failure ($9 - 12,000), childbirth by Caesarean section ($5 - 10,000), heart attack ($9 -19,000.), knee and lower leg procedures ($9 - 15,000), disc surgery ($8 - 16,000.00). These are costs in Massachusetts hospitals. And these are just the hospital costs for the surgery, your surgeon will bill you also.

http://www.boston.com/business/graphics/052711_hospital_costs/

With a US median annual family income of $44,000.00 for a family of four, it seems that most people couldn't begin to pay for any of these without good insurance. It's no wonder that the chief cause of personal bankruptcy in the US is medical debts.

As for "patients will ask more questions and be incentivized to avoid unhealthy behaviors", that's too simplistic. We demonize people who smoke or who are fat, etc., but most people do take care of their health and the health issues I listed above can happen to anybody.

"Savings won’t just disappear. They’ll go into other purchases, often ones that are more valuable, like higher education or rapid transit, creating construction jobs while making our commutes easier. "

This kind of comment gets to the real problem with the mind set of health care economics. How do you say that healthcare purchases are less valuable than other purchases? Where is the evidence for such a statement? The bottom line in this debate is that the American public really does not understand the true value of healthcare since they don't directly pay for it. Payment for the most part occurs through multiple intermediaries such as the employer and an insurance company, therefore shielding the receiver of the care from the real costs. The only choice we have to control costs is direct payment from the patient to the care provider. Patients will ask more questons and be incentivised to avoid unhealthy behaviors. Providers will actually have to compete with each other on quality and value. No politician has the courage to propose this. Unfortunately, we are heading in the opposite direction toward a single payer system which will result in less patient responsibility, and either continual cost increases or limitations and rationing of care.

States that have instituted "reforms" that have substantially reduced the number of malpractice suits have not reduced the cost of health nor the frequency of tests and treatments. Defensive medicine is a myth. In fact, in a letter to Senator Hatch, the CBO wrote that an ideal system of tort reform would not lower costs by any more than 0.5%, 0.3% of which would be due to less "defensive medicine,"

References: page 150 ff of http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/99xx/doc9924/12-18-KeyIssues.pdf, and http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/71xx/doc7174/04-28-MedicalMalpractice.pdf,

Here is the relevant paragraph from the letter to Senator Hatch:

"CBO now estimates, on the basis of an analysis incorporating the results of recent
research, that if a package of proposals such as those described above was enacted, it
would reduce total national health care spending by about 0.5 percent (about $11 billion
in 2009). That figure is the sum of the direct reduction in spending of 0.2 percent from
lower medical liability premiums, as discussed earlier, and an additional indirect
reduction of 0.3 percent from slightly less utilization of health care services."

We can control health care costs by :
1. Adopting Medicare for all-from cradle to grave.
2. Reward doctors for quality of care, not quantity.
3. Eliminate direct to consumer advertising of drugs.
4. Strengthen the FDA to ensure safety and efficacy of new drugs.
5. Tort reform regarding medical malpractice and reducing "defensive medicine".
6. Elect representatives who believe in the above.

Not exactly true - for example in the RA field multiple studies have demonstrated the efficacy of triple therapy vs. therapy with methotrexate alone, and have demonstrated that biologics provide much better efficacy when used in combination with methotrexate. Studies have looked at whether to " step up " RA therapy rapidly or gradually using single drugs or multiple drugs. A lot of research is not quite as simplistic as you make it out to be, just looking at whether or not a single agent works.
And the length and number of studies in the RA field essentially rule out a counfounding factor such as gluten that could be skewing multiple lengthy studies that have gone on for 6 -24 months. As well as the fact that studies routinely control for variances in the groups that are being studied.....
This is just an example from the field of Rheumatology, but it can be applied to all areas of medicine currently being studied.
